title: Millennium Villages Project
summary: The Millennium Villages Project, led by Jeffrey Sachs, invested $120 per person per year in integrated development interventions across 14 sites in 10 African countries. While the project reported improvements in health and agriculture, the absence of a rigorous counterfactual drew sustained methodological criticism.
content:
## Background

In 2005, economist Jeffrey Sachs, director of Columbia University's Earth Institute, argued in his bestselling book *The End of Poverty* that extreme poverty could be eliminated through targeted, scaled-up investments in basic needs. Sachs contended that the poorest communities were trapped in a "poverty trap" where income was too low to generate the savings needed for productive investment. He proposed that a "big push" of coordinated investments in health, agriculture, education, and infrastructure could lift communities above the threshold needed for self-sustaining growth.

This theoretical framework drew on earlier development economics, particularly the work of Rosenstein-Rodan (1943) and Sachs, McArthur, and Schmidt-Traub's (2004) calculations of the costs of meeting the Millennium Development Goals. The Millennium Villages Project (MVP) was conceived as a proof of concept: demonstrating that integrated, community-level interventions could achieve the MDGs in Africa.

## The Intervention

The MVP operated in 14 village clusters across 10 Sub-Saharan African countries: Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Malawi, Mali, Nigeria, Rwanda, Senegal, Tanzania, and Uganda. Each site served approximately 35,000–50,000 people. The project invested roughly $120 per person per year in project funds, supplemented by government and community contributions that brought total investment to approximately $300 per person per year.

Interventions were deliberately comprehensive. In health, the project distributed insecticide-treated bed nets, provided community health workers, and upgraded clinics. Agricultural interventions included distribution of improved seeds and fertilizers, training in farming techniques, and support for market access. Education components focused on school meals, teacher training, and school construction. Infrastructure investments included boreholes for clean water, rural roads, and electricity connections.

The integrated approach was the project's defining philosophy. Sachs argued that piecemeal interventions failed because poverty's dimensions were interconnected: a farmer could not benefit from improved seeds without health to work the land, education to adopt new techniques, and roads to reach markets. The MVP aimed to demonstrate that addressing all constraints simultaneously could produce synergistic effects greater than the sum of individual interventions.

## Results & Evidence

The MVP reported significant improvements across its sites. According to the project's own assessments, under-five mortality declined by 22%, malaria prevalence fell substantially in sites where bed nets were distributed, maize yields more than doubled in several locations, and primary school enrollment increased.

Mitchell et al. (2018) published the final independent evaluation of the MVP, comparing outcomes in MVP sites with matched comparison villages. The evaluation found statistically significant improvements in some outcomes, including child mortality and agricultural productivity, but the magnitudes were generally smaller than the project's own reporting suggested. Notably, many comparison villages also showed improvements over the same period, reflecting broader national trends in health, education, and economic growth across Africa.

Palm et al. (2017) found that the MVP achieved meaningful health improvements, particularly in maternal and child health, but that attributing these gains specifically to the project was complicated by the absence of a pre-registered randomized design.

## Challenges & Criticisms

The MVP attracted sustained and sometimes fierce methodological criticism. Clemens and Demombynes (2011), in a widely cited paper, argued that the project's evaluation design was fundamentally flawed. Without randomized assignment or a credible quasi-experimental comparison, it was impossible to determine whether observed improvements were caused by the MVP or would have occurred anyway due to secular trends, government programs, or other factors. They demonstrated that several MVP claims about progress on MDG indicators could not withstand scrutiny against appropriate counterfactuals.

The lack of randomization was a deliberate choice by Sachs, who argued that the integrated, community-wide nature of the intervention made randomization impractical and that the ethical imperative to act outweighed methodological concerns. Critics responded that without rigorous evidence, the project could not demonstrate that its specific approach was more effective than alternative uses of the same resources.

Cost-effectiveness was another concern. At $120+ per person per year, the MVP was expensive relative to targeted interventions (e.g., bed nets at $5 each, deworming at $0.50 per child). Economists like Banerjee questioned whether the same resources deployed through proven, targeted interventions would have achieved greater impact.

Sustainability after external funding ended was also a significant question. Some improvements, particularly in infrastructure and health worker training, appeared to persist, while others, notably agricultural input subsidies, proved difficult to maintain without continued external support.

## Key Lessons

- Integrated development interventions can produce measurable improvements but are difficult to evaluate rigorously without randomized designs
- The absence of a credible counterfactual severely limits the ability to attribute changes to any specific intervention
- Big-push approaches may not be more cost-effective than targeted, evidence-based interventions
- Sustainability requires building local institutional capacity and financing mechanisms, not just demonstrating short-term gains
- Demonstration projects, regardless of results, need rigorous evaluation designs to inform policy decisions

## References

1. Clemens, M.A. & Demombynes, G. (2011). "When Does Rigorous Impact Evaluation Make a Difference? The Case of the Millennium Villages." *Journal of Development Effectiveness*, 3(3), 305–339.
2. Mitchell, S., Gelman, A., Ross, R., et al. (2018). "The Millennium Villages Project: A Retrospective, Observational, Endline Evaluation." *The Lancet Global Health*, 6(5), e500–e513.
3. Sachs, J.D. (2005). *The End of Poverty: Economic Possibilities for Our Time*. New York: Penguin Press.
4. Pronyk, P.M., Muniz, M., Nemser, B., et al. (2012). "The Effect of an Integrated Multisector Model for Achieving the Millennium Development Goals and Improving Child Survival in Rural Sub-Saharan Africa." *The Lancet*, 379(9832), 2179–2188.
